Hands-on Exercise 6

Author

Shaun Tan

Published

May 19, 2023

Modified

May 25, 2023

1. Installing the requisite R packages

pacman::p_load(plotly, tidyverse, corrplot, ggstatsplot, tidyverse, ggcorrplot)

require(devtools) install_version(“ggtern”, version = “3.4.1”, repos = “http://cran.us.r-project.org”)

library(ggtern)

2. Data Prep

2.1 Importing the Data

#Reading the data into R environment pop_data <- read_csv(“data/respopagsex2000to2018_tidy.csv”)

2.2 Preparing the Data

#Deriving the young, economy active and old measures agpop_mutated <- pop_data %>% mutate(Year = as.character(Year))%>% spread(AG, Population) %>% mutate(YOUNG = rowSums(.[4:8]))%>% mutate(ACTIVE = rowSums(.[9:16])) %>% mutate(OLD = rowSums(.[17:21])) %>% mutate(TOTAL = rowSums(.[22:24])) %>% filter(Year == 2018)%>% filter(TOTAL > 0)

3. Plotting Charts

3.1.2 Plotting Basic Ternary Diagrams

#Building the static ternary plot ggtern(data=agpop_mutated,aes(x=YOUNG,y=ACTIVE, z=OLD)) + geom_point()

3.1.2 Adding Colors and Aes to the Basic Ternary Diagram

#Building the static ternary plot ggtern(data=agpop_mutated, aes(x=YOUNG,y=ACTIVE, z=OLD)) + geom_point() + labs(title=“Population structure, 2015”) + theme_rgbw()

3.1.3 Building an interative Ternary Diagram using plotly()

reusable function for creating annotation object

label <- function(txt) { list( text = txt, x = 0.1, y = 1, ax = 0, ay = 0, xref = “paper”, yref = “paper”, align = “center”, font = list(family = “serif”, size = 15, color = “white”), bgcolor = “#b3b3b3”, bordercolor = “black”, borderwidth = 2 ) }

reusable function for axis formatting

axis <- function(txt) { list( title = txt, tickformat = “.0%”, tickfont = list(size = 10) ) }

ternaryAxes <- list( aaxis = axis(“Young”), baxis = axis(“Active”), caxis = axis(“Old”) )

Initiating a plotly visualization

plot_ly( agpop_mutated, a = ~YOUNG, b = ~ACTIVE, c = ~OLD, color = I(“black”), type = “scatterternary” ) %>% layout( annotations = label(“Ternary Markers”), ternary = ternaryAxes ) ```

4. Visual Correlation Analysis

4.1 Installing and Preparing the Data Set

Importing the data

wine <- read_csv(“data/wine_quality.csv”)

Building a correlation Matrix

pairs(wine[,1:11])

pairs(wine[,2:12])

Drawing the lower corner

pairs(wine[,2:12], upper.panel = NULL)

Drawing the upper corner

pairs(wine[,2:12], lower.panel = NULL)

Including the correlation Coefficient

panel.cor <- function(x, y, digits=2, prefix=““, cex.cor, …) { usr <- par(”usr”) on.exit(par(usr)) par(usr = c(0, 1, 0, 1)) r <- abs(cor(x, y, use=“complete.obs”)) txt <- format(c(r, 0.123456789), digits=digits)[1] txt <- paste(prefix, txt, sep=““) if(missing(cex.cor)) cex.cor <- 0.8/strwidth(txt) text(0.5, 0.5, txt, cex = cex.cor * (1 + r) / 2) }

pairs(wine[,2:12], upper.panel = panel.cor)

Using ggcorrmat() to visualise a correlation matrix

ggstatsplot::ggcorrmat( data = wine, cor.vars = 1:11)

ggstatsplot::ggcorrmat( data = wine, cor.vars = 1:11, ggcorrplot.args = list(outline.color = “black”, hc.order = TRUE, tl.cex = 10), title = “Correlogram for wine dataset”, subtitle = “Four pairs are no significant at p < 0.05” )

Grouped ggcorrmat()

grouped_ggcorrmat( data = wine, cor.vars = 1:11, grouping.var = type, type = “robust”, p.adjust.method = “holm”, plotgrid.args = list(ncol = 2), ggcorrplot.args = list(outline.color = “black”, hc.order = TRUE, tl.cex = 10), annotation.args = list( tag_levels = “a”, title = “Correlogram for wine dataset”, subtitle = “The measures are: alcohol, sulphates, fixed acidity, citric acid, chlorides, residual sugar, density, free sulfur dioxide and volatile acidity”, caption = “Dataset: UCI Machine Learning Repository” ) )
